page.title: 12Industry at Froghall Wharf
page.content: Froghall Wharf on the Caldon Canal was used for loading limestone into the narrowboats. The limestone was then taken to Stoke-on-Trent. The canal was built in 1779. The limestone was transported from Cauldon Low to the lime kilns at Froghall by a tramway. The limestone was used for fires, roads and fertilizers. Lime kilns were built over the course of the Shirley Brook so the brook was culverted. In 1849 the North Staffordshire Railway built the Churnet Valley line through Froghall. Limestone travelled down the rope tramway to sidings at Froghall and the canal. 80 years ago the line to Cauldon Low was built and so the stone travelled directly by rail. The canal wharf declined, and all the traffic ceased by 1950. It became a scrapyard.
